text: Patient: I need two weeks off. Doctor: Yeah. No, no, no, we’ll figure it out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s just keep things moving and we’ll figure it out. Patient: So J___ told me that his promise to you is he said he’ll get me squared away medically and then - Doctor: Yes, and then it’s time for us to take over! (chuckles) Patient: Yeah. ___ called me last night. He said we’re taking a break in oncology and we’re going to do some medicine. And I said okay. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That really made me feel good, for you, too, and for me. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Because I was like “You’ve got to do that or I get derailed from what I have to do.” Patient: Right. Doctor: So he’s on it.

text: Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Um to arrange a consultation, or a timely consultation with Dr. T in his clinic, which is in the building. Patient: Um, hum. text: Patient: Potassium. Doctor: That's right. That's for the secondary causes of hypertension. Okay. Okay, so that is, so that's that approach. The third approach is clinical trials. And clinical trials in general are where we're testing some intervention to see if it is helpful or not. The two that we have for people who have biochemical recurrence, there's one that's a natural products. And there's one that is a medicine called a PARP inhibitor. Patient: Mm. Doctor: The mainstay of treatment of prostate cancer today is hormone therapy, neither of those two therapies are hormone therapy. Okay, so the clinical trials that we have would be doing, they would be giving you some intervention, but it would not be a hormone therapy intervention. So sometimes people like that because they don't want to get started on hormone therapy. Because if your disease progresses, you got to get started on hormone therapy- Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: -and sometimes people, you know, don't want to be in a clinical trial. And so these are, the three general options. Family Member: Out of the three which one would you recommend. Doctor: Well, let me tell you a little bit more about what what the clinical trials entail, because then I'll tell you what I think, based on our conversation last time to what we should look into first. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So the two clinical trials one is called the MAP study. And I might have briefly mentioned this last time, this is a study of muscadine grapeseed extract. Family Member: Yes you did. Doctor: Yeah. So this is a study- is a randomized study for people with a particular genotype. So what that means is what what we know is that when some people take antioxidants like you know, these a lot like pomegranate or the muscadine grapeseed extract- Family Member: Mhm.

text: Patient: Okay, would that be your recommendation, to do more hormonal? Doctor: Well, I was gonna, I was gonna talk to you about that. Um… Patient: Right. Doctor: I think it it probably - some type of hormone therapy is probably gonna be in your near future. It might not be the immediate future, but I think sooner rather than later given that we’ve tried this sort of outside-the-box non-hormonal type of therapy and it hasn’t really you know worked as well as we had hoped, the next step I think given that the PSA is rising and given that this lymph node is increasing, I do happen to believe it’s prostate cancer would lead me to the conclusion that hormone therapy is probably the next best thing to do. Patient: Now with hormonal therapy, um it is not a cure. It’s just a uh–. Doctor: That’s correct… It’s - Patient: Okay, so it’s not a cure. The only thing it would be doing is slowing down the progress of the, it would slow down the - Family Member: No. Aggression. Patient: The aggression. Yeah. Family Member: Aggression. Doctor: Right. I wouldn’t say it’s the only thing that it’s doing because that’s doing a lot already. Patient: Uh,hum. Doctor: It’s not just slowing the progression. It is actually killing cancer that’s already there as well. So it is actively killing cancer and starving it of testosterone. You are correct in the sense that um we don’t think that this hormone therapy can eradicate all the cancer leading to a cure so that if you stopped the therapy the cancer would not come back. So we do think that it’s a very, very good treatment that reduces remissions, causes remissions –

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And in, in having an immune drug on board seems to make that whole thing work better. Um, I don’t have the answer for this vaccine radium combination, whether it’s going to do anything. But that’s, that’s the idea behind it is let’s bring these two things together. Uh, so, uh, again, if I had to say which one has the best chance of working for you right now is probably going to be a second hormone treatment. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and I think given where you are with the disease in the bone- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I, I would probably lean towards something that I’d feel like we have a better chance of, of success. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, even though some of these things sound cool, I don’t really have a good sense of, you know. text: Patient: So what’s goin’ on, so what’s goin’ on with my bones? Doctor: Nothin’. Patient: He just said that somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: No. I didn’t say anything. Patient: The other doctor that came in before him, before Dr. P_, said somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: Oh. Doctor: G_? Healthcare Professional 1: He had progression on his bone scan and CAT scan. That’s what he might have gone through. Doctor: Oh, could be. But his bones are not progressed. It’s just the, um, lymph nodes. (Pause) Patient: No. Doctor: I’m the one bringin’ it up because I see it on the scan. Oh!! We gotta do something. We gotta do something. But, from a functional day-to-day, it’s not really buggin’ you. If you were peeing poop, it would bug you. You would know it. It would frighten the heck out of everybody, but that’s not what’s happening. So, here’s a chance where we can proactively think about it and not wait until it’s an emergency. Patient: I’m not peeing poop.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, then and so, all that works from a time frame. Then, the counts, the next week which you’re getting - I don’t know if that’s for the study or - then you can get that at LabCorp. That’s gonna come to us. Uh, we don’t do much with that. That’s more if you call us, and you say, “Hey, you know, I have a fever.” We can look at those blood tests and say, “Hey, it’s low. So, you should go to the hospital.” Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, it’s normal. You’re like everybody else. Just take your Tylenol or whatever. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, and we’ll get you a chemo teaching class. Patient: Okay. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
